sections.heading: Transmission-Based Precautions
sections.text: CDC Transmission-Based Precautions (Appendix A examples). Airborne (N95/respirator; AIIR if available): tuberculosis (pulmonary/laryngeal), measles, varicella (chickenpox), disseminated herpes zoster (shingles; and sometimes zoster in immunocompromised depending on extent/policy). Droplet (surgical mask for close contact): influenza, pertussis, meningococcal disease, mumps, rubella, early/untreated group A strep pharyngitis, adenovirus respiratory infection, Mycoplasma pneumonia; RSV is often managed as droplet + contact. Contact (gown + gloves for room entry; dedicated equipment): C. difficile (soap-and-water emphasis), norovirus, scabies, major impetigo, draining wounds/abscesses not contained by dressings, uncontrolled diarrhea, and MDROs per facility policy. Combinations are used when indicated: droplet + contact (RSV, parainfluenza, human metapneumovirus, adenovirus, seasonal coronaviruses, sometimes influenza); airborne + contact (varicella, disseminated zoster, smallpox); airborne + droplet (e.g., SARS/avian influenza or novel respiratory pathogens under investigation; often add contact + eye protection).

sections.heading: Resident rights: refusal and informed decision-making
sections.text: Federal regulations include resident rights related to informed choices about care, including the right to refuse treatment. Documentation should reflect the resident’s stated refusal, education provided, risks/benefits discussed, alternatives offered, and follow-up plan.

sections.heading: Quality of care: change in condition response
sections.text: When a resident’s condition changes, nursing assessment, timely notification, and appropriate interventions/monitoring are expected. Record objective findings, baseline comparison, provider notification, orders, and resident response.

sections.heading: Accidents and supervision (falls risk)
sections.text: Facilities must take reasonable steps to prevent accidents and provide adequate supervision/assistive devices. Post-fall documentation should include circumstances, injury assessment, neuro checks if indicated, notifications, and prevention plan updates.

sections.heading: F-tag mapping: use citations in packets
sections.text: Appendix PP provides interpretive guidance used by surveyors. When generating packets, include the relevant F-tag context (e.g., Resident Rights, Abuse/Neglect, Infection Control) and tie your actions/documentation to objective evidence and facility policy.

sections.heading: Abuse/neglect: immediate protection + reporting + investigation
sections.text: Survey expectations emphasize immediate resident protection, timely reporting, thorough investigation, and documentation of findings and follow-up. Notes should include who was notified, when, what protections were implemented, and the investigation status.

sections.heading: Infection control: program expectations
sections.text: Survey guidance on infection control focuses on an active program, implementation of precautions, staff education, and documentation that supports decisions (signs/symptoms, testing, isolation, monitoring).

sections.heading: Core practices: hand hygiene + PPE selection
sections.text: Core IPC practices include consistent hand hygiene and selecting PPE based on anticipated exposure. Documentation and audits should focus on adherence to core practices and staff education/competency.

sections.heading: Core practices: environmental cleaning and disinfection
sections.text: Environmental cleaning and disinfection are key core practices. For outbreaks, emphasize high-touch surfaces, correct disinfectant use, and clear assignment of responsibilities.

sections.heading: Core practices: respiratory hygiene/cough etiquette
sections.text: Respiratory hygiene and cough etiquette reduce transmission of respiratory pathogens. For symptomatic residents, include source control, masking per guidance, and timely evaluation/testing as indicated.

sections.heading: LTCF infection prevention: resident/family education
sections.text: CDC LTCF resources support education for residents, families, and caregivers on preventing infections in nursing homes and assisted living facilities. Use these materials to reinforce hand hygiene, vaccination, and reporting symptoms early.

sections.heading: LTCF prevention focus: early symptom recognition
sections.text: Emphasize early recognition of new symptoms and prompt reporting to nursing staff to reduce spread and complications. Pair with facility policy for triage and provider notification.

sections.heading: NHSN LTCF Component: surveillance and process measures
sections.text: NHSN LTCF Component supports tracking infections and prevention process measures to identify problems, improve care, and monitor progress. Consider aligning facility line lists and surveillance logs with NHSN concepts.

sections.heading: Common LTCF modules: UTI, MDRO/CDI, vaccination
sections.text: NHSN LTCF includes modules relevant to nursing homes (e.g., UTI, MDRO/CDI, HCP flu vaccination, prevention process measures). Use these as a reference framework for consistent surveillance documentation.

sections.heading: Respiratory viruses: prepare and respond in nursing homes
sections.text: Toolkit actions include preparation steps, symptom-based response, testing considerations, and escalation when respiratory illness is detected among residents or staff. Use for influenza/RSV/COVID-19 season planning and outbreak response.

sections.heading: Outbreak workflow: line lists and communication
sections.text: Maintain clear line lists, communicate with leadership and public health as required, and document cohorting/precautions decisions. Ensure staff education and consistent PPE use.

sections.heading: SBAR structure for provider notification
sections.text: SBAR provides a structured way to communicate changes in condition: Situation (what is happening now), Background (baseline and history), Assessment (your findings), Recommendation (what you need/next steps). Use SBAR in notes to show clear escalation.

sections.heading: SBAR documentation cues for LTC/SNF notes
sections.text: In documentation, capture: objective findings (VS, symptoms, timeline), baseline comparison, what was communicated to provider, orders received, interventions performed, and resident response/monitoring plan.

sections.heading: Change in condition communication: early warning tools
sections.text: AHRQ LTC tools include early warning/communication supports to help staff recognize and communicate changes in condition. Integrate into your wizard by prompting for objective findings and clear escalation steps.

sections.heading: Team communication training: standardize the message
sections.text: Use standardized communication (e.g., SBAR) and team training to reduce missed information during a change in condition. Pair with documentation checklists and packet citations.

sections.heading: QAPI: link findings to education and re-audit
sections.text: CMS QAPI resources emphasize systematic improvement: identify a problem, implement interventions (including staff education), measure outcomes, and sustain changes. Use this to power closed-loop QA → Education → Re-audit workflows.

sections.heading: QAPI governance: leadership and accountability
sections.text: QAPI at a Glance highlights leadership responsibility, data-driven improvement, and ongoing performance monitoring. Use this as an executive-language reference in survey packets and QAPI minutes.

sections.heading: NY nursing home resident rights: key themes
sections.text: NYSDOH resident rights resources emphasize dignity, respect, communication, and participation in care decisions. Documentation should reflect education provided, resident preferences, and involvement of representative when appropriate.

sections.heading: NYCRR 415.3: resident rights baseline
sections.text: 10 NYCRR 415.3 describes nursing home responsibilities to protect and promote resident rights, including dignity, privacy, and self-determination. Use when building refusal-of-treatment packets and documenting resident-centered decision-making.

sections.heading: NY reporting expectations: suspected abuse/neglect
sections.text: NYSDOH outlines reporting requirements for suspected abuse, mistreatment, and neglect. Documentation should include immediate protections, notifications, and the status of investigation/reporting per policy.

sections.heading: NY investigation report: what to include
sections.text: The NYSDOH incident/abuse reporting materials support consistent investigation reporting. For packets, include objective findings, timeline, actions taken, notifications, and follow-up/monitoring.

sections.heading: NY complaint process: resident/family pathway
sections.text: NYSDOH provides an online complaint form and hotline information. Include this reference in resident rights packets when concerns escalate beyond facility grievance processes.

sections.heading: What this memo changes (high level)
sections.text: CMS issued QSO-25-14-NH to revise long-term care surveyor guidance. Use this memo as the “why” behind Appendix PP updates and align facility education, audits, and packets with the updated expectations.

sections.heading: Effective date and rollout
sections.text: Treat the updated surveyor guidance as effective on the stated CMS rollout date; ensure staff education, competency checks, and audit tools reflect the revised interpretive guidance and critical element pathways.

sections.heading: Why NHSN LTCF tracking matters
sections.text: Use NHSN LTCF component concepts to standardize infection tracking and prevention measures. A consistent surveillance approach supports outbreak detection, QAPI trending, and documentation that is easy to defend.

sections.heading: Line list discipline
sections.text: Maintain a clean line list during clusters/outbreaks: who, what symptoms, onset dates, test results, unit/room, isolation status, and outcomes. Keep it current and use it for escalation and reporting.

sections.heading: Antibiotic stewardship in nursing homes (program focus)
sections.text: Use a nursing-home-specific antimicrobial stewardship framework: define criteria for suspected infection, improve communication (SBAR), and monitor antibiotic starts, indications, and durations as part of QAPI.

sections.heading: Documentation cues for suspected infection
sections.text: When antibiotics are considered, document the suspected source, objective signs/symptoms, relevant vitals, test plan, and monitoring/escalation plan. Avoid vague “UTI” language without clinical criteria.

sections.heading: Do not treat asymptomatic bacteriuria (LTC)
sections.text: In older residents in long-term care, bacteriuria without symptoms is common. Use clinical criteria before treating; do not screen or treat asymptomatic bacteriuria unless specific exceptions apply (follow provider/facility protocol).

sections.heading: When UTI is complicated
sections.text: Use provider guidance and clinical criteria to distinguish uncomplicated lower urinary symptoms from complicated UTI (e.g., obstruction, systemic illness, instrumentation). Document reason for concern and escalation plan.

sections.heading: Core elements of infection prevention in LTC
sections.text: A strong LTC infection prevention program includes surveillance, outbreak response, staff education, hand hygiene/PPE, environmental cleaning, and reporting to public health when required. Tie infection control work to QAPI.

sections.heading: Notifiable disease reporting expectations
sections.text: Maintain a system to recognize and report notifiable diseases to public health. Document who was notified, when, and what data were provided (line list, labs, case counts).

sections.heading: Purpose and scope
sections.text: Use a structured antimicrobial stewardship program in nursing homes to improve antibiotic use, reduce harms, and support appropriate diagnosis and treatment decisions.

sections.heading: When to suspect infection vs colonization
sections.text: Focus on resident-specific signs/symptoms and avoid treating colonization; document objective findings and clinical rationale for starting or withholding antibiotics.

sections.heading: Start, monitor, and maintain
sections.text: Establish facility goals, track antibiotic starts, review cultures and durations, and provide feedback/education to prescribers and staff.

sections.heading: Documentation essentials
sections.text: Document indication, symptoms, tests obtained, prescriber notification, orders, start date, planned duration, monitoring plan, and resident response.

sections.heading: Tools and templates
sections.text: Use standardized forms/checklists (e.g., SBAR, stop-and-watch, antibiotic time-outs) to ensure consistent communication and decision support.

sections.heading: Early recognition and response
sections.text: When respiratory symptoms are identified, implement a structured response: assess, consider testing per guidance, and apply appropriate source control and precautions.

sections.heading: Cohorting and precautions
sections.text: Use appropriate precautions (standard + transmission-based as indicated), consider cohorting residents/units, and reinforce PPE/hand hygiene.

sections.heading: Outbreak communication
sections.text: Maintain line lists as needed, communicate with leadership and public health per policy, and document education and monitoring.

sections.heading: What NHSN LTCF tracks
sections.text: Use the NHSN LTCF Component to track infections and prevention process measures over time to identify trends and improve care.

sections.heading: UTI and MDRO surveillance concepts
sections.text: Standardize definitions and reporting approaches for events like UTI and MDRO/CDI to support consistent surveillance and benchmarking.

sections.heading: Process measures
sections.text: Use process measures (e.g., hand hygiene, PPE, vaccination, prevention bundles) to drive improvement work alongside outcome measures.

sections.heading: Infection prevention program elements
sections.text: Maintain an organized infection prevention program with surveillance, education, policy oversight, and outbreak response capability.

sections.heading: Hand hygiene and PPE fundamentals
sections.text: Reinforce hand hygiene and PPE selection based on risk assessment; use audits and feedback to improve compliance.

sections.heading: Outbreak detection and response
sections.text: Establish triggers for outbreak detection, initiate control measures promptly, and coordinate reporting to public health when required.

sections.heading: Employee health considerations
sections.text: Include staff illness reporting and work restriction guidance, vaccination programs, and exposure management as part of infection prevention.

sections.heading: Integration with QAPI
sections.text: Align infection prevention work with QAPI: track data, prioritize improvement projects, and document interventions and outcomes.

sections.heading: Avoid treating ASB in LTC residents
sections.text: In older residents of long-term care facilities, avoid screening for or treating asymptomatic bacteriuria; focus evaluation on symptoms and objective findings.

sections.heading: Documentation tip
sections.text: Document presence/absence of urinary symptoms and objective findings; if no symptoms, document rationale for not treating and monitoring plan.

sections.heading: Effective date awareness
sections.text: Appendix PP revisions take effect on the stated CMS effective date; facilities should align training, audits, and policies accordingly.

sections.heading: Training and readiness
sections.text: Prepare staff and leadership by reviewing revised pathways and guidance, updating facility processes, and ensuring documentation supports compliance.

sections.heading: Start here: safety, baseline, and urgency
sections.text: When a change of condition is reported, first determine immediate safety/medical urgency, compare to baseline, and obtain objective data (vitals and focused assessment) before escalation. Document a clear timeline (what changed, when, who observed) and the resident response to interventions.

sections.heading: Behavior / agitation / new confusion: red flags
sections.text: Escalate immediately per facility emergency protocol for any danger to self/others, severe aggression, suspected stroke symptoms, severe respiratory distress, uncontrolled bleeding, or rapidly declining level of consciousness. Ensure safety measures and obtain assistance early.

sections.heading: Behavior / acute mental status change: reversible causes checklist
sections.text: Assess for common reversible contributors: pain, constipation, urinary retention/UTI symptoms, fever/respiratory symptoms, dehydration/poor intake, hypoxia, hypoglycemia, medication changes (new meds, dose changes, PRNs), sleep disruption, and environmental triggers. Obtain vitals and compare to baseline; perform focused neuro/mental status assessment.

sections.heading: Refusal of medication/treatment: informed refusal steps
sections.text: Clarify what is refused and why; assess understanding/decision-making capacity as appropriate; explain risks/benefits and alternatives in plain language; offer reasonable alternatives (timing, formulation, comfort measures) when safe; re-approach per plan; notify provider and resident representative/EC as indicated; document education provided, resident statements, notifications, and follow-up plan.

sections.heading: Refusal: documentation that surveyors expect
sections.text: Document: (1) the specific med/treatment refused, (2) resident stated reason, (3) education provided and response, (4) capacity/representative involvement when applicable, (5) provider notification and orders, (6) safety monitoring and re-approach plan, and (7) any harm-reduction steps taken.

sections.heading: New symptoms: triage and escalation
sections.text: Capture objective data first: full vital signs, symptom onset/time course, baseline comparison, and focused assessment (respiratory, urinary, GI, wound, neuro, pain). Escalate promptly for chest pain, new unilateral weakness/facial droop, acute shortness of breath, persistent SpO2 decline, uncontrolled bleeding, or rapid deterioration.

sections.heading: Provider notification: SBAR template
sections.text: S: What changed and why you are calling now. B: Baseline diagnosis/status, relevant history, recent meds/changes, allergies. A: Objective assessment (vitals, focused findings) and what you think is happening. R: What you need (orders, transfer eval, labs, monitoring parameters) and what you have already done.

sections.heading: Packet-building: what to attach (survey-ready)
sections.text: For survey-ready packets, attach: facility Change-of-Condition policy (documentation and notification expectations), any relevant F-tag/Appendix PP interpretive guidance section(s), resident rights reference for refusals, and the SBAR template. Include citations with source title and effective date/last update, plus a concise event timeline.
